comments.commentBody:
Mr. McGreevey was closeted gay man who tried, more than once, to play roles defined for him by straight society, until he could no longer carry the pretense. He resigned after admitting a homosexual affair with a subordinate staffer and came to terms with his orientation. Nothing particularly evil or unusual in that, and he seems to have turned his lemons into lemonade, found inner peace, and now devotes his time and abilities to helping others.

To characterize his prison work as "creepy" or "trolling" is to engage a stereotype that the facts simply do not bear out and paint him as a soulless predator. Alexandra Pelosi's new documentary should decisively put the lie to what can only be seen as a cheap shot.

Besides, among recent New Jersey governors, he seems relatively unpretentious...

Sophia: I'm guessing McGreevey is counselling female priisoners because many of them have suffered sexual abuse or exploitation at the hands of significant others, and it is presumed that, as a gay man, he can be trusted by both the women themselves and the prison authorities not to take advantage of them. Their being able to see him as a person, and specifically as a man, whose interest in them is not sexual is a valuable asset in a counseling relationship.

The article is about people with a driving need to be "loved" by everyone with whom they deal, and how dysfunctional that it. It applies as much to McGreevey, who did not abuse any women other than his wife, as it does to all the rest. It is not an article about sex abuse, it is an article about emotional neediness and the dangers and compromises resulting.

And yes, it is creepy to see McGreevey now filling his needs on these very vulnerable people.

It is creepy to know that McGreevey is now trolling through the emotional needs of female prisoners, as their counselor.  If he did not do enough damage already, this gives him a whole new slate of potential victims, many very vulnerable.
The law is what Antonin Scalia says it is . . .

Those who claim there never used to be any gun restrictions had better check into the facts. Back in Jim Crow days, the southern states made it a crime for a black person to carry a concealed weapon.

The law is what those in power say it is. There is no unlimited right to bear arms. The Supreme Court has ruled as such.

I have a bumper sticker for Rep. Stockman: If people stopped electing idiots for public office, more young people will live to see their grandchildren
That pretty much describes most of the so-called mainstream media.

You left out the type of journalism that has sold its soul to one side, right or wrong, and will say anything to justify that side no matter what they have done at the moment.  You ought to know that sort of journalist.  Don't leave that out.

We are, as a nation, conflicted with how we feel about our alpha males and females. The leaders of the pack are no longer given the benefit of the followers looking the other way when the the very qualities that make a leader get subverted in some way. We want our leaders to be great, but somehow, more than human. We want our emperors to be godlike in a very roman way.
Weiner was a good, caring, and effective congressman. That he has a thick enough skin to go through what he went through, and still believe that he can be mayor of NYC is all the qualifications he needs for that office.

Just because people made a mistake doesn't mean we should abandon them. And just because some people voted for anti-abortion leaders doesn't mean we should make others who didn't or changed their minds leave their homes and communities for abortions. Thinking like that leads only to a world where no one cares for anyone else.

I suppose, then, that if a state decided imprison all gun owners for owning guns, you would insist that gun owners refuse to file a legal challenge and simply emigrate to another state. Or if a state decided to confiscate the property Jewish people, they should immediately pull up their stakes and emigrate.

What is it about constitutional rights that you do not understand?

The Governor and the legislature in Kansas and Arkansas and North Dakota have gone too far. We will be taking back the people's House next year.
Abortion is legal and upheld by the United States Supreme Court. Restricting access is not.

If the people of the state voted for an anti-abortion state government, I strongly object to helping them with an abortion clinic.  That old remedy, which created Americans in the first place - emigration to escape oppressive government - is still valid.  I would have the blue states welcome refugees from the red.  People are free to make stupid choices and cannot be shielded from the consequences thereof.

I think Mr. Bruni's piece is spot on, yet his observations about the need for attention, love and approbation go way beyond politics. I recognize the symptoms in my own life, especially in my business career. It wasn't enough to be financially rewarded. There had to be more - there had to be a kind of rockstar-like recognition. Applause was always welcomed - even demanded - but criticism? What was there to criticize?
This kind of behavior is common and has always existed in politics. There just seems to be so many more public outlets for it today.

Because many of the things that made our country great did not result from bipartisanship. For example, the Medicare, Welfare, Medicaid, and Social Security were largely enacted by a completely partisan majority.

Compromise is is generally good, but it does not automatically end up with a good result. His point is that the result is more important than the process. Even if the process is "bipartisan," if the result is worse legislation (such as the affordable care act or any number of other bills) than you should criticize the bill instead of praising the process.

If the media ran more like Mr. Douthot proposed we would have real news and not a pseudo entertainment industry.

You say: "the capacity and willingness to work together to solve great national problems, ..."
So we have had all the vested interests working together so they can keep making the same outrageous profits. So these vested interests manage to pay their own people the benefits that are then foisted off on the government to pay, so everyone gets taxed to pay just those people the government then can decide with its rules set up in connivance with those same vested interests, ... keeping the rest of the people from getting those benefits. Then also 'providing' for those unfortunates who actually have been kept out of this establishment by those very interests, and claiming to help these who otherwise would fall through the very safety net that those vested interests contrived to create.

I read the article and did not feel that Douthat is writing as a conservative. I think it is a mistake to classify people as conservatives in advance of listening to them.

The Times HAS no real right wingers writing for it - and that is good. I doubt that Fox would publish an article by Douthat. What the Times has is some columnists who are center right and urge the Times' mostly liberal readership to consider other ways of thinking about our problems besides liberal dogmas.

Such columnists like Douthat or Brooks or (on occasion Friedman) deserve to be listened to and not dismissed as conservatives.

Why is it that, whenever conservatives don't like the message, they rush to shoot the messengers?

Bipartisanship is not a media fetish. It is part of what has made this country exceptional: the capacity and willingness to work together to solve great national problems, pragmatically and not ideologically. It's what the American people want and it's what they are not getting.
I'd rather have a Barack Obama, warts and all, than a George W. Bush, who said that God spoke to him and said it was just fine and dandy to invade Iraq.

If the Second Amendment allows the government to bar private citizens from owning stingers (indispensable weapons in uprisings against tyranny), it allows the government to regulate access to assault rifles.

I had my first direct encounter with this type of personality disorder while working as a an assistant for a reasonably successful research scientist. Every moment of his existence seemed to be spent in perpetual anxiety that someone somewhere might not think he was the most wonderful, brilliant person in the world. Every move was a calculated to engender an expression of admiration, congratulations, awe. What a pathetic way to live one's life.

groupbrat, As you suggest, the UN role could have been the best option, however it seems unlikely, given the high stake geostrategic interests of concerned nations, and their capacity to influence the UNSC decision making. Moreover, the UN itself seems to have ceased to be a major factor, let alone an impartial arbiter, at resolving global/regional conflicts, specially since 9/11 and Iraq invasion days. As to North Korea being a puupet regime to China, there's no doubt about it, as the former's survival has largely depended on the latter, being the sole lifeline to keep NK alive by meeting its food / fuel needs. However, there comes a time when even the vassal regimes too start proving a risky liability, and need correcting. The China-NK ties seem currently undergoing that critical test, hence the US could leverage that situation to restore stability and peace on the Korean peninsula and surrounding region, of course with China on board without ruffling its feathers, meaning latter's legitimate geopolitical and stability concerns. Thanks.

Following TUSH with 'cheek by jowl' paints quite a picture in the mind's eye. "FM-only" Chomsky is a great little throwaway, and I agree that Cardinale's In...mmm, right after Loren.

Always fun to read your posts.

Lasz, WOOD YEW, by any chance, be trying to start arROW with archer's everywhere?

BOQ

Lasz, You're right on the honey, as CLAUDIA always obeyed the Cardinale rule!

Howie

This was a very workwomanlike puzzle, well constructed, with a sweet theme that made me get up and have a piece of that dark-brown heaven.

I wasn't crazy about the large number of blocks, or the over-all discombobulated appearance of the grid. But this is Sunday, so we must have and overabundance of theme answers to the detriment of the overall puzzle, don't we?

The multiple pockets of isolated micro-puzzles did not float my boat. What did? All that CHOCOLATE.

I thought SISI & GIGI so close to each other looked sorta cute.

I was confused. I thought the 22A and 69D clues were switched, because I'm almost sure John TUSH is a new age pianist. Here he sits cheek by jowl with our old friends RAHM Emanuel and "FM-only" Chomsky. Not the ideal company, if you ask me.

For me there is only one CLAUDIA, and that is Cardinale. She would be perfect company.

How do you address an archer's wood source? "Hey, YEW TREE over there!"

Enjoy the rest of your Sunday.
"It is" denotes agreement; contracted  "it is" becomes TIS. 'Taint so?

Just noticed IT IS at 46D.

That's Gorski-clever.

Hey Leapy, I didn't notice the clever clue for TIS until you pointed it out. Contracted, wow, that's good.
That shows to go you how much of a puzzle you can solve without ever seeing the clues, just from crosses. And how much fun you can miss thereby. Speed solvers, take note.

This really happened, I swear. Just before starting the puzzle, I was freezing in my den, even though I had pulled on a sweatshirt over the long-sleeved shirt I was wearing. It suddenly hit me that the very thing I needed was a steaming cup of hot chocolate—something I very rarely drink. By the time I finished the puzzle, I had to acknowledge that some EERIER-than-usual emanation from the grid must have led me to that unusual choice.

I know I'm gonna feel dumb when I see the answer, but can someone please explain TIS (28A) to me?
@MLechner, so are we supposed to care about border security, or not?

@CR: Oh, I know all about pit bulls and all the work. Mine is a rescue--a West Philly "Special" as those of us in rescue call them.

I know all about breed-specific legislation and that pit bulls are banned in areas across the globe. Denver bans pit bulls but not firearms, go figure! They actually went door-to-door, using licensing info, and confiscated them--no grandfathering.

I know how hard it is to get homeowner's insurance and that, basically, you have to self-insure. Meaning, you can be sued and are liable for any damages to people, or other animals.

I know that where I live now, I am required to muzzle my dog if he's off private property. So I am actually breaking the law when I walk him, un-muzzled, around my block.

Basically, I wanted to discuss AngryDad's post today, even though it's a little dated. I feel the irony of the argument is truly underappreciated.

@dwb: I almost agreed with you, but then re-read your post!

Weapons need to be confiscated from any domestic situation that requires public intervention. Once the police need to knock on your door, you no longer have the "right" to have firearms--for the safety of everyone involved.

If you can't keep your business private and need help on the taxpayer dime, you lose your individual right to have weapons.

I mean, we have to protect our taxpayer investment, such as law enforcement, social service workers, firemen, etc.

When our public officials are shot and killed by accused (not convicted) domestic abusers, it costs us in pension payouts to their family, medical care, funeral care, disability payments, rehab, higher insurance premiums due to increased risk, etc.
Time in service, I think.

Fascinating to note, among other inconsistencies in this survey, that for questions #9 (Should citizens be required to complete a safety training class before being allowed to
buy a gun?) 43% of the law enforcement officers responded NO, but in answer to question #23 ( Do you support arming teachers and/or school administrators who volunteerto carry at their school?) 76.6% responded "Yes, if they are vetted, trained, and qualified annually"

Should we assume from this that unless they are in school, our children are at the mercy of gun-toting civilians who have no safety training, no vetting, and no requirements for annual re-qualification? Oh -- and the aforementioned probably won't need background checks of any kind either, once our legislators have rolled over for the NRA.

BTW -- Have any statisticians out there analyzed the formulation of the survey and the manner in which data was collected?

Just asking.

"Auto makers relentlessly research ways to make their products safer, and mitigate the results of improper use. Firearm makers are the antithesis of this."

Of the 30,000 firearm deaths each year about 20,000 are suicides. There does not appear to be a correlation between firearm ownership and suicide rates by country, as unfortunately it appears that substitution takes place. One needs to address the reasons for suicide and not just try to restrict access to the means.

Less than 10,000 firearm deaths a year are due to homicides, where product safety is a moot point. That leaves the 606 accidental deaths due to firearms in 2010, compared to the over 35,000 motor vehicle deaths. The motor vehicle death rate could be dramatically reduced if every vehicle had a 35 mph speed limiter, a roll cage, and everyone was required to wear a helmet.
We can start by dismissing dwb and beadyeye.  They havent contributed anything to this conversation in months.

MR, I have completely lost what ever was your point, in these emotions. What was/is your point? Let us talk about that, eh?

Secondly, the only issue of fact was: I asserted that wrongful death claims often exceed 4 M$ each, and you claim either that they don't (which is obviously refutable, I am not even going to bother), or in some way "not the norm," or perhaps "not the average." These issues are side points to me, but if you want to get into this, be my guest, WITH SOME REAL DATA.

Let us now move to a point which you seem to entirely misunderstand:

"You then cited a highly publisized case and mentioned that they settled for a million(1/4 of what you were saying). They only paid that amount because of the cases notoriety, making it a really bad example."

The homeowner's association settled ITS liability (not Zimmerman's, and perhaps not too theoretically the Sheriff's department's) for a sum "well OVER 1 M$". That might possibly be 4M$, but candidly I doubt that.) This is NOT the full liability and was settled in advance of Zimmerman's trial, to avoid the price it would surely cost afterwards if Zimmerman is convicted.

And then MR, yes, it is a notorious case. Gun murders are generally notorious ... on the scale of it this one is actually more defensible than most. Zimmerman does have a defense.

You need to understand that the public won't settle gratuitous gun murder deaths at the same price they'll settle "Suzi fell into an unwatched pool."

DWB ... Oh. please ... this is pathetic. You are claiming that it is "racist" to have an aversion to guns and those who carry and use them, particularly to those who MISUSE them? And you are claiming that because Clairette thinks of gun owners and users rather the way I think of nicotine and methamphetamine addicts, that she must have been a white racist? Be really funny if Clairette is black.

It's a choice to have a gun, it's a series of many choices about what gun you have, how you keep it, what you use it for and when. You are aware that I have owned guns in the past, technically do so right now, might choose to do so in the future, depending on circumstances?

Yet at this moment I have no operable guns, particularly would not keep one in my home. My "relationship" to guns is not like yours at all. I have no emotional attachment to them, indeed dislike them -- in my terms they are like badly-engineered airplanes -- widow-makers, but sometimes, and for some purposes, one does "need" to fly them, or at least somebody does. There was a while when I was younger and less risk-averse when I made my living flying bad airplanes -- that was low risk to other people though.

When you look at the carnage guns cause, it's caused by people who are some combination of stupid, reckless, in a rage, an irrational panic, or homicidal/suicidal.

How can you possibly be surprised that the ordinary public has a low opinion of gun owners? You want respect? Stop the carnage!

Reasonable estimates of the costs of gun-violence in the US range from 14 B$ to in excess of 100 B$ per year. I've no idea where you got that 3 B$ number but it is certainly too low.

Yes, the gun crowd wants the "right" to externalize the costs of the carnage onto the rest of the public. And in this regard, sadly the Newtown killings are the perfect example.

Nancy Lanza was the perfect model of the "gun enthusiast" ... until she wasn't. Any rational accounting of the costs she imposed on others by her recklessness would surely exceed 100 M$ -- exceed it by large margins if one tries to assess the consequences to the community too, or indeed the whole of American society.

There was no rational reason Nancy "needed" those guns. It is obvious they were not for "self-protection."

Yet we've got Wayne and the NRA telling all of America that WE need to pay the cost of armed guards at all schools and public places in perpetuity ... so gun nuts can have these guns, and we'll STILL have shootouts at school with children in the middle?

The gun nuts don't get it. But in time they will.

The reality is unfortunately simple: the NRA actually does want criminals to have guns. Gun manufacturers want criminals to have guns, it's good for business.

Criminals buy guns, duh. They may not buy new guns directly, but they buy or steal them from other gun owners, who will then buy a replacement.

And when criminals get caught with guns, that gun is destroyed, so another gun will get sold to enter the chain.

And of course criminals with guns do ugly things which drive the demand of non-criminal people to have guns. The escalation of fire-power we see now, which is all that is keeping the gun market afloat, is all about this. Criminals with guns are the advertizements of the gun industry.

And the Republican party has become the party of the gun industry. This is as awful and foolish as the Republican party having become the party of dog-whistle white racism, and religious fundamentalism and ignorance ... but there you go, they are all of a piece.

DWB, shame on you. You know the answer to "Why aren't we seeing mass shooters use full auto?"

I never want to hear you hector anyone else out there about their supposed lack of knowledge about guns, after you have pulled a stupid rhetorical trick like this one.

Same reason those military full-auto guns have a selector switch, which is almost always on single or three-shot-burst. Full-auto is only useful for "supression fire" -- a squad level tactic most common in an ambush situation, meaning when the ARMED ENEMY is firing at you, from a better position than yours, and you are in a squad, and it's time to run or dive into the ditches (hoping they aren't filled with punji sticks or deto-cord and claymores, or IADs etc)

Shooting at the unarmed and defenseless, you want to pick your shots. That uses your ammo more effectively.

Adam Lanza was fairly efficient at killing helpless school children. His mother and those shooting clubs taught him well enough.
